column3: <font color="green">S-a-n-c-h-e-z, James Madison University, September 25, '04.</font>

<font color="#008080">Sonia, Gwen said in one of her poems, 'This is the urgency; Live!/ and conduct your blooming in the noise of the whirlwind.' I know because of our long association, that it has not always been easy to be a black poet in the second half of the 20th century, or the first decade of the 21st century.</font>
<font color="#008080">Could you talk about that a little bit? How have there been those difficulties?</font>

<font color="green">Well, you know, I think that it's been difficult, you know, all the years that we've been here in this place called America, being writers, or even poets, because you do know that teaching in the English department, they really didn't think that we belonged there, because it is called 'English Department'. However, we did go there, and we did make somewhat of a [inaudible] splash.</font>

<font color="green">But also what you know-- reading early literature, you understood finally, how difficult it was for DuBois, how difficult it was for Phyllis Wheatley, how difficult it was for Delaney and all those people, Zora, to write and to be accepted as writers in this whole interesting thing called writing in America-- what they call the canon, the literary canon.</font>

<font color="green">And quite often we ourselves are not even accepted into that canon, at this stage of the game, after all of these years of really what I call invigorating this thing called American writing. That's what we've done. We have invigorated and stretched it.</font>

<font color="green">When you began to include Black writing, in, in this writing, then it opened up to Native American writers, it opened up to Jewish writers. I mean, within the genre, it opened up to Asian writing, Women's writing, you know, Lesbian Studies, Gay Studies. And what it did is it spread all out and said, simply, you know, here we is, you know, it is not all about European writing.</font>

<font color="green">And that made for such an interesting way of looking at the world, and looking at literature. I mean, you had, you have this very wonderful literature that goes on and says, you've got to look at something called Westward Expansion with a different eye, you know, than saying, by golly, by gee, we were just going out west to expand, no, you also killed a whole lot of people, you know, doing that also, too.</font>

<font color="green">So all that was necessary. So it meant that you had to look at the words of the Native Americans, you know, you had to understand that this was not just them, chanting, going 'Ooga booga booga', like African writing, you know, or going 'Aayayah-wuhwuhwuh' but listen, and we did that we brought that within that arena. And I remember once reading in the Midwest, and a Native American person came up to me and said, ah, sister Sanchez, when you chanted, I heard my people.</font>

<font color="green">And I remember leaning back, I leaned back on my own breath, and felt his breath and knew the connection. Which was so important to us, because at first, you were so interested in bringing just the word of the African American writing, that you didn't always hear other people breathing around you.</font>

<font color="green">But once you were able to firm yourself and look out at the world, at the diaspora, you heard other breaths, you smelled other breaths, you heard other chants, you say, this is the same chant. These are the same words. And these are the same kind of things that are happening.</font>

<font color="green">When I went to China in '73 we were in Hong Kong waiting for a train. And this Chinese man came darting across the-- we were the first group, after Nixon had climbed the Great Wall of China, and so we had people like Candice Bergen and Alice Childress, and, you know, all kinds of people going there, the San Francisco Mime Troupe, the people who had been white-listed, you know, in America at McCarthy, those writers were on that trip. </font>

<font color="green">And this Chinese man came running across the, the train station, crazy in ragged clothes. Everybody jumped, and I stood and said how you doing, brother? Because see, I've seen you in Harlem, you know, I've seen you in Chicago. I've seen you in Alabama. Hello, how you doing? You know. So it's the same, and you begin to understand that, then you understand your literature more, and you understand the world's literature more, also too.</font>

<font color="#008080">Writing out of this frenetic chaos that we are so used to. A young woman stood up yesterday in the conference and talked about being from Pakistan and how we have to make a connection with the women in Pakistan because our experiences as women in this country are similar to those that she experienced growing up there.</font>

<font color="#008080">And I thought about the theme of the conference, at least the sub-theme, 'Cross Pollination in the Diaspora', because we have to understand that our poetry has stretched far beyond our boundaries, and has impacted many, many people. And I know that your poetry has done that, because you are affectionately called the poet of the universe. And why do you think people call you that?</font>

<font color="green">I don't know, but the point is that I think we have learned, you know, that we all have the same voice, as I said before. When I was in China in '73, and I was reading my poetry at University of Beijing, one of the professors stood up and said, 'Ah, professor Sanchez. We understand this really well', they said,</font>

<font color="green">What you said... we've been in Shanghai, and he said, you know, and you're talking about your black experience, he said, but you know, here in China, they had signs in Shanghai that said, 'no Chinese or dogs allowed'. So what you do is that you understood, it was indeed-- that oppression, against people of color was a real oppression all over the world.</font>

<font color="green">And so when we began to write what we wrote, at some point initially we thought, this is just this experience, this is just my pain. And I had to tell people, by golly, by gee, this is all our pain, you know, here, and you know, all of it. So therefore, the greatest thing I think that happened to me, and probably to you and a lot of us in this field, is that we taught, you know, and in teaching-- I always say to people, teaching makes you-- writing and teaching will keep you human.</font>

<font color="green">You know, because you will be in a classroom-- I remember teaching at Temple University up at the, up the art campus, and this young white man walked in with his hair all dyed, and he very obviously was gay. And I was in my classes, you know, in a circle, and nobody wanted to grab his hand.</font>

<font color="green">So I grabbed his hand and told this young woman 'you grab his hand', you know, and I held on very tightly, and I said, you're in this circle, you know, everyone's in this circle. And he was such a great writer, that by the third week, everybody wanted to hold his hand.</font>

<font color="green">So it is important for us as writers, you see-- I did a long essay, 'The Poet as Creator of Social Values'. We who create these things, we who say and set the tone for history-- when 9/11 happened, where did they go? They didn't go to the diplomats, they went to the poets, and say help us understand this tragedy, help us to understand what has happened, help us to breathe, because we're not breathing, now, in this particular place, help us to live.</font>

<font color="green">And writers and poets have always helped people to live. And the question that must be answered here in the 21st century is that-- What does it mean to be human? If, if we don't answer that question, we're all doomed. You know, this is like, this is not like, what does it mean to be human if you're Black, or if you're Puerto Rican, or if you're Asian, or if you're gay, or if you're Jewish, or if you're Muslim or whatever?</font>

<font color="green">No, what does it mean to be human on this earth? Because if you don't answer it, this Earth is gonna swallow us whole and say I'll wait billions of years for some more of you to come out of the sea. I mean, this is serious business going on right now at this particular time. So I say to my students all over, we've got to begin to answer this question in a very real concerted effort, you know, no half-sliding here, no half-stepping here at all, these are serious times. Period. </font>
<font color="#008080">You have to remember that, when you taught that year at Lincoln University, it must have been 1975.</font>
<font color="green">Sure was. Ooh. I was teach--</font>
<font color="#008080">Oh, no maybe, maybe it was later.</font>
<font color="green">Later, no it was about '77, or '78.</font>
<font color="#008080">It was 19--</font>
<font color="#008080">Yes, yes, you came in then. I remember coming to your class, and you did the ritual of holding hands at the end of the class, and having--</font>
<font color="green">Yeah, making a circle.</font>

<font color="#008080">Making a circle and having the students say something supportive, something positive about someone in the class, and I picked up that ritual. I don't do it at the end of every class like you do. But I certainly do it at the end of every semester. But the whole idea is to-- how-- whole idea is to really come up with a way of making the students feel connected. And when you do that, in the classroom, you model what can be done in the community.</font>
<font color="green">Outside the classroom.</font>
<font color="#008080">If you do that in the community, you model what can be done in the world. And it seems to me your perspective has always been the extended community, You know.</font>

<font color="green">Yeah, I mean, even when we first came on the scene-- and you know, one of the things that you see is happening, when people really want to, in a sense, not open their eyes and listen, I'm always so, so surprised at people who have formed an opinion of you in 1965, and they still have the opinion in 2004. It shows two things. It's shows that the person has not grown, and the person thinks you have now grown.</font>

<font color="green">It's like the great Brecht, you know, did, used to do, like these little small pieces similar to what Baraka does, you know? And he says in it, a friend came up and said, 'How are you doing? How are you doing? How are you feeling?' You know? And he says, 'I'm doing fine, I'm doing fine.' He says, 'and you haven't changed a bit.'</font>

<font color="green">And, and he looked at him in a very strange way and said, 'There's something wrong with that'. Why? Because, if you haven't seen me in 20 years, my sis, you better believe I've changed. The wrinkle here is for a reason, you know, you know, the crease here is for a reason. You know, the gray hair is for a reason. You know, I don't, I mean-- someone said, 'Well, why don't you just dye that hair, Sonia. So then-- and don't tell your age, because then people won't know,'</font>

<font color="green">I said, I want people to know that I have lived these years. I want people to know that this is what this is about. And this right here came from a demonstration, you know, when I turned, and I was knocked down, you know, and I got up-- couldn't get to ice, because I wasn't in my house, putting ice on it. So therefore every time, initially, when someone looked at it and said, 'Oh God, Sonia, that's terrible there'. And I looked at and I said, you know, uh huh. It could be terrible, but it could be for a reason, too.</font>

<font color="green">And I think everything is for a reason, you see, at some particular point. And I think that is what is important. I was just in Rome, for this great Interdependence day. And you had prime ministers and, and diplomats from all over the world. And I opened the conference with a poem that I did about Interdependence day, because the theme is that we're all interdependent as people, you know, in our own countries, in our separate countries, and then in the world, countries are interdependent.</font>

<font color="green">And when we truly understand that, then we move on a different level with each other. Because then you don't say to the person, I'm going to bomb-- you bomb me, then I bomb you next. When you're interdependent, then you go to people, then, who can say how do we reconnect because we've gotten disconnected at some point?</font>

<font color="#008080">Exactly. Because I was thinking that there must be some people in Iraq today, who are so convinced that they are being under-- they're under attack. I'm sure they have in their heads, this poem by Countee Cullen, 'If we must die let it not be like hogs/ Hunted and pinned, in some inglorious spot'.</font>

<font color="#008080">We have to really understand that they are just like us, they feel like us. And sometimes we let the media convince us that what is going on over there has no connection with us, at all.</font>
<font color="green">Right. Not Countee. Yeah. Yeah, I was just saying that's--</font>
<font color="#008080">What?</font>
<font color="green">That's not Countee. Oh, I'm sorry. </font>
<font color="#008080">Did I say Countee?</font>
<font color="green">Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Right. Yeah, that's all right. We'll correct it.</font>
<font color="green">Yeah, right.</font>
<font color="#008080">Oh no, it's not Countee, that's right. I said Countee Cullen.</font>
<font color="#008080">Alright. It's Claude McKay.</font>
<font color="green">Yeah, Claude McKay.</font>
<font color="#008080">Yeah, that's exactly right, yeah.</font>

<font color="green">Yeah, 'If We Must Die'. My sister, what we truly understand at some point, is that we have, all over the world, bunches of old men and women, you know, who know one way to deal with the world. And that is through fire, through killing, through bombings, through, you know, oppression, whatever.</font>

<font color="green">What we're saying at some point, what I tried to say to the young people yesterday, is that there's a new way of looking at the world. And one of the ways that we have moved with our poetry, you know, going from one point to another point-- when I first came on the scene, as other people came on the scene, we didn't know we had been enslaved. So we went into the library and said, Wow, God, we were enslaved, no one told us-- for insatance my momma didn't tell me I was enslaved-- when we found that out, what did we do? We were-- we attacked everybody, then--</font>

<font color="green">everybody, didn't matter who you are, were like, 'bu-bududu', and even our parents. So, America said, How could you attack me? I've been good to you. Why are you calling me those names? Like, whitey, whatever. And you know, because-- I said to someone finally, well Black [inaudible] folks have always called you names.</font>

<font color="green">Only because we had no power. So the best thing to do was like-- and I said that, but that's a Black thing. I mean, that's like when I grew up, you know, in Harlem, you played the dozens, you know, you signified on people. So I said to-- a long interview with someone that (which they never printed) in the New York Times, I said, this is about signifying, you know, so you cannot review a book of my poetry or anybody's poetry, unless you understand the culture of the people. You assume that you raised us all just like Topsy.</font>

<font color="green">We are saying, you did not raise us like Topsy, you know, we come with new information. So when I write this particular poem, you've got to come with information. For instance, when I used to teach Yeats, and I came across a poem, and I said now is he into mystical stuff here? You know, is he into whatever.</font>

<font color="green">So there was an authority on Yeats and I knocked on his door at Temple, and I sat down-- and I sat down with him, he said, 'Sonia, you're right. Very few people pick that up.' And I said, well only because I was a poet, another poet reading him. So I said, well, talk to me about it. He did, I took notes, you know. From then on that man spoke to me on that campus, but he hadn't done it before.</font>
<font color="#008080">Yeah. He respected you, yeah.</font>

<font color="green">So I said, if you're going to teach me, you just can't walk in and teach me or some of these other people, without understanding that there's a culture, but if you understand there's a culture, then you assume, then-- the assumption must be you're human. You know?</font>
<font color="#008080">What was the cultural moment for you, when you knew that you were going to be a writer?</font>

<font color="green">Oh gosh. You know, I think... I do think I might have known that at an early age. But it was, um... I always know, when I teach a workshop, the people who really truly have talent, and are really born poets, right? And the ones who just learned it, and can write a poem through, you know, craft, and that's about it.</font>

<font color="green">But I-- Well, I began to write poetry after my grandmother died when I was six, you know. And, but I didn't take it seriously, it was just something I did. But it saved my life, after my grandmother had died, after mama had died.</font>

<font color="green">But I think in a very serious way, I-- all through, during my university years, I would take these little writing classes, and it was like, I was always like, ignored, whatever etcetera. And so even when I got out of Hunter and was going to NYU, I'd do these workshops, and they would talk about everybody's poem-- now, I'm not writing anything radical, I'm just writing. But the point is that I look back on it now writing my memoir now, I was the only woman in there, and I was the only Black. So poetry was all for white males,</font>

<font color="green">you see, not even women. Adrienne Rich says, (in one of the anthologies she says), I really got up on stage one day and announced, I am a woman poet, okay, after I read the black poets in America, who were saying, I am a black poet. And that's why I'm talking about the kind of influence that we had on people, because we identify ourselves, you know, from jump street, you see.</font>

<font color="green">I really discovered it when I studied with a woman by the name of Louise Bogan. You go into American literature, and there she is, fine poet and editor for The New Yorker. You know, I mean, the poetry editor for The New Yorker. I walked into a class of 45 people at NYU, my sister. I sat by the door, because no one had ever wanted to even discuss what I was writing,</font>

<font color="green">and the first night she says, Does anyone have a poem? That's like asking a bunch of alcoholics, if they got a bottle someplace. We all went in our pockets, like this, you know, I went in my pocket, and I raised my hand and said find out now, but I raised my hand. She said, Come up front, tell me your name. I did. I read the poem and she... the whole class went [raises hand], responds to it.</font>

<font color="green">First time I had response, you know, and she said, 'And if you had really read that poem out loud, Sonia, you would have heard the following'. And like, Lo, I stayed. I studied. And then I finally asked her one day in her office, I said, I want to know, do I have talent? She said, 'What do you want to know that for Sonia?' I said, well, I said I'd like to know, because, you know, I wanna know if I'm wasting-- I didn't say that, because I really didn't think I was wasting my time, right?</font>

<font color="green">Because it was in that workshop that I published my first poem. Out of all that class, and I brought in bottles of wine to NYU, you know, at night, you know, and passed it around with little cups. And because she taught us from the jump street, the first day, she said, get a notebook. Put down on one side the Nation, Address, day sent, three poems, no more than three poems, New Yorker, the Mass Review, New England Review, page, page, and start sending your poetry out.</font>

<font color="green">I did it, you know. First time I sent it, however, I took it to the mailbox across from where I lived, right? And by the time I got back home, the reply was there. No, thank you, right. But I--</font>
<font color="#008080">But it's so empowering to do that.</font>
<font color="green">It is-- I make my students do it in workshop.</font>
<font color="#008080">Yeah. Yeah. I do that, as well, yeah.</font>

<font color="green">Oh, yeah. You know, and when I'm editing something, or someone else is editing something I say, write them with this poem, it's good, tell them you're in my workshop. And you know, you've seen my students get published, along with major poets, you see. That is what you do. You push this thing called poetry, because poetry is one of the most important things that will keep us human on this earth. </font>
<font color="#008080">Yeah, we did a children's workshop yesterday. And the poems that came out of that workshop. Amazing for 12 to 14 year olds.</font>
<font color="green">Oh, no, not at all. </font>
<font color="#008080">And that young--</font>
<font color="green">Yeah. The one that read last night, yes.</font>
<font color="#008080">The one she read was just wonderful.</font>
<font color="green">Wonderful.</font>

<font color="#008080">She talked about all of the different positive aspects of being Black, you know, and darkness, that was really wonderful. You know, I was thinking, you read a poem yesterday, and you called it a 'Poem for Some Women'. </font>
<font color="green">Yeah.</font>

<font color="#008080">And, what was the impetus for that poem? It's a very painful poem. A colleague of mine, walked out of the auditorium and was visibly moved, and told my husband, he just thought that was one of the most powerful poems he'd ever heard read.</font>

<font color="green">My sister I was watching television one night, you know, at the end of the day. I was getting my tea to go upstairs to, you know, sit-- plop, prop myself up a bit and write or read before I went-- go to sleep. And the news cast came on and this woman said today, today, today, it was reported that a woman in North Philadelphia (which identified her as Black, or Puerto Rican, right, Latina, you know), took her child into the crack house and left her. And then there was this silence, which meant like, Oh, those people do terrible things to their children.</font>

<font color="green">And I went upstairs trying to forget it. And I even, you know, read a bit, you know, brushed my teeth, you know, washed my face, pull the covers up, and got up in the middle of the night, and started writing that poem. And that poem is for some women, not all women.</font>

<font color="green">That poem is about the question that I wrote in the margin, always-- I always ask my students when they're writing, what is the first question that comes to your head that motivates you to write this poem? The question was, how have we gone from women on the slave auction blocks, you know, saying master master, please don't take my child away from me. How have we gone from there to taking that child in the crack house and leaving her for a week?</font>
<font color="#008080">Yes.</font>

<font color="#008080">You know, and it was in that space, that I began to write that poem. You know, in that woman's voice, you know, who is still human. You understand? When you just do the cold facts, she's not human. She has no breath. She has no blood. She has nothing except, that's what she did, you see. But the woman is human, you know. I mean, this woman who lives in her neighborhood, you know, and can get crack, you know. She can find the crack house, but the police can't find the crack house.</font>

<font color="green">But the children can tell you where the crack house is, you know. Everybody on the block can tell you where the crack house is, and it never gets busted, you know what I'm saying? So here she is, marching in, and she sees this man who says, 'I don't want you' she says, 'I'm gonna give you my body'. And he says, 'I don't want you,  but I want a virgin'.</font>

<font color="green">What kind of person? What kind of male, you know, looks at 11, a 10, a nine, an eight, a 12, a 13-- I'd go up to 16, even, you know-- year old, and you see, you know, you don't see a human being you know, you don't see a little girl, right? You know, but you see a virgin. How can you call a 12 year old a virgin? That's a little girl, maybe one day removed from dolls.</font>

<font color="green">So I wanted to have all of that in that piece, you see. And this woman-- and she comes back singing 'Mama's little baby loves shortening, shortening, Mama's a little baby loves shortening bread. Put on the jacket, put on the jacket'.</font>

<font color="green">Because you see, one of the times when I'm pushed up against the wall with some people, and I have moved to a point where I don't curse people out, you know, where I don't attack-- you know, go and say get out of my face, you know, you're in deep trouble, [inaudible] or whatever. But I'd say you know, can you tell me my brother, what I did to offend you? You know, right. And then sometimes people say 'well lalalala', I said, well, I'll come back to you. You know, we'll talk later, and I walk away. But I might walk away humming.</font>

<font color="green">Because the humming gets me through that next moment, you know. That humming, makes me understand at some point, there are some people, you know, who really have been taught never to go below this area. They've never been taught to go to the heart, or even the bloodstream, or even the mind, or above the mind at all. That their thing is always let us be combative. Let us-- oh, let me stay right here in the gut, and in the other part, in the genitals, you know what I'm saying?</font>

<font color="green">Then, but the country keeps you on that level. If it can keep you hungry always, and stuffing your mouth with food, you know. If it can keep you always looking at fighting, people fighting all the time so you get a hard on, you know, like, 'Woooo, did they get that--', whatever, you know, if they can keep the young girls itching all the time to jump in somebody's bed, you know, because she thinks that's gonna make her a woman, you know, then you control the populace.</font>

<font color="green">But if you move their eyes up to the heart, and if you have a heart, you know, you do not kill. You know what I'm saying? You know, and if you have a mind, you'll look at it in a different way and begin to say, Aha, but if you have the spirit, you know, spirit mixed with the mind, also, do you know what I'm saying? The spirit and the soul with the mind, then something else happens.</font>

<font color="green">And it has been that kind of motion and movement that I've tried to do with my poetry. And in that piece, that's a hard, piece because all of a sudden, I don't think you remember that poem when I read to you years ago, and I said, and then Joanne I said, I have moved to another level, I don't write this kind of poem anymore. And then I heard myself say it later on. I said, oops, what are you saying? If it's happening, you can't move-- you can't move to another level what do you mean you've moved to another level, girl catch yourself, you know, watch yo mouth as the old folks used to say, you know, girl, watch yo mouth, what are you saying.</font>
<font color="#008080">Other directions maybe. Are there--</font>
<font color="#008080">Yeah. Yeah.</font>
<font color="green">Of course there are other directions!</font>

<font color="green">But the point is what I understand is that I can do this piece-- a very middle class woman said to me, 'Ah, Professor Sanchez, I just love your poetry. It is so lyrical. But why would you why something like this?' You know? And that's like, just recently-- you know, in the airport, when, you know, they grab you because you you're talking about the country and the war, and Bush and all this stuff, you know, that's happening. And Halliburton(?), you know, they--</font>
<font color="#008080">Then you've become a security risk.</font>

<font color="green">Yeah. And they said, they said-- and they tag you, you know? Well, Grace Paley, the writer, all of us. I mean, the ACLU called me and said, you know, it's a list with all you peace people on it, you know what I'm saying? So we want you to know, so I put my name on the thing, where they were going to file to get that list, so it could be published as such. But they grabbed me-- but I'm coming out of Syracuse, my sister.</font>

<font color="green">And the woman never looks up, the guy didn't even-- nothing went 'ding ding ding ding ding ding'. Nothing with ding, ding, ding, ding at all. But he saw the color code that they have on there. He said, we need you on the side. So I said, Oh, is there a problem? I didn't hear anything go dingaling, dingaling. You know? And he said simply-- well, yeah, that's what I was told. I mean, I was told by the brothers outside, but I wanted him to say it too, because his [inaudible] they won't say it.</font>

<font color="green">They just say oh, this is just something that we do with a few, you know, chosen people. But he said it because he saw me looking at him. So the black woman came along, she never looked up at all. She just said, come this way, grabbed my briefcase, and my purse, and she says, 'stand back, Stand back'. And so, she opened my purse, and she took my stuff and threw it like it was dirt. And dirty.</font>

<font color="green">And I stood there just looked at her. I kept looking at this sister thinking, you know, mmm, mm, it's hard, you know, you know, it's hard being human. And then she opened my brief-- then she put my stuff in-- threw it back in, no order. Zipped it. Then she opened my briefcase and the first thing she saw was my picture on a book, and she said 'Miss Sanchez'. She looked, she said 'Oh'-- looked at me for the first time.</font>

<font color="green">And I thought how often we go through life, jobs, all over and we never look people in the eye. Because we're afraid of what we will see. We will see ourselves when we look people in the face, and we don't want to see ourselves sometimes.</font>

<font color="green">She said 'why'-- she whispered, 'why are they doing this to you'? I said my sister-- and I whispered back 'they're doing'-- I leaned over, 'they're doing it because I'm talking about the war, against the war, about peace, whatever  et cetera', she said, why don't you stop?
